questions.question: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent delayed ischemia in the acute phase of subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nimodipine Explanation: Nimodipine is used to prevent delayed ischemia in the acute phase of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage management: Nimodipine 30–60 mg IV for 5–14 days, followed by 360 mg orally for 7 days. Prevents delayed ischemia in the acute phase of SAH. Aneurysm Management Endovascular coiling Surgical clipping Arteriovenous malformation Management Surgical removal. Ligation of feeding or draining blood vessels. Injection of material to occlude fistula or draining veins. Complications Treatment Obstructive hydrocephalus: May need shunt drainage. Delayed cerebral ischaemia (vasospasm): Treated with vasodilators. Hyponatraemia: Managed by fluid restriction. Systemic complications (immobility): Manage chest infections and venous thrombosis. Nifedipine (Option A): It does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and is not used to prevent cerebral vasospasm or delayed ischemia in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Amlodipine (Option B): Long-acting calcium channel blocker used for systemic hypertension and angina. Like nifedipine, it lacks specificity for cerebral vessels and is not effective in preventing delayed cerebral ischemia after SAH. Felodipine (Option D): Dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used in managing hypertension, but it has no proven benefit in preventing cerebral vasospasm or ischemia post-SAH. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine 24th edition, page 1162

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with progressive weakness in his arms and legs over the past three months. On examination, he has hyperreflexia in the upper and lower extremities and bilateral weakness is noted with poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas. Based on the presentation, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: noted with poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas) indicate intramedullary compression of the spinal cord. Intramedullary compression of the spinal cord: Pressure exerted on the spinal cord from within typically due to a lesion such as a tumor, abscess or other pathologies. Causes Intramedullary Tumors: Ependymomas Astrocytomas Hemangioblastomas Abscesses (pyogenic or tuberculous abscesses) can create masses within the spinal cord. Multiple sclerosis: Inflammatory demyelinating lesions may cause intramedullary effects. Trauma Cystic lesions : Such as syringomyelia, where a cyst forms within the spinal cord. Clinical features Motor Symptoms: Weakness or paralysis in the limbs, typically presenting as bilateral weakness. Reflex Changes: Hyperreflexia and spasticity below the level of the lesion. Pain: Poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas(sacral sparing). Diagnosis MRI of the Spine: The gold standard for identifying intramedullary lesions . CT Scan Neurological Examination: Detailed assessment to identify the level and extent of dysfunction. Extradural compression (Option A) and Intradural compression (Option B): Both are extramedullary compression of the spinal cord which usually presents with radicular pain and sacral sensory loss. Foramen Magnum syndrome (Option C): Usually presents with crural paresis and does not present with poorly localized burning pain.

questions.question: A patient presented with complaints of radicular pain on the lower back associated with loss of sensations over sacrum and urinary incontinence. There was weakness, started over lower limbs one month back and now weakness is present over upper limbs. What is the ideal imaging of choice to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation: early Bladder involvement is suggestive of e xtramedullary compression of spinal cord . MRI preferably T2-sequence is the ideal imaging of choice to diagnose spinal pathologies. Extramedullary Compression on Spinal Cord: Causes Intradural: Benign Neurofibroma ; Slow onset of symptoms seen Extradural: Spinal metastases from Breast/lung/Prostate cancer; Relatively rapid onset of manifestations seen Clinical features Radicular (root) pain along the nerve root involved Early sacral sensory loss Ascending spastic paralysis starting from lower limbs Bladder involvement - early DWI (Option A): Diffusion weighted imaging is mainly helpful in cases where Spinal infarct is suspected. CT (Option C) & X-ray (Option D): Are among the initial imaging of choice mainly in Bone pathologies related to spine like Intervertebral disc prolapse, etc.

questions.question: Which among the following is the least likely manifestation in this spinal cord lesion (as shown below)?

options.A: I/L loss of vibration sense at the same level
options.B: C/L loss of pain at the same level
options.C: I/L loss of vibration sense 2 segments below the level of lesion
options.D: C/L loss of pain 2 segments below the level of lesion

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) C/L loss of pain at the same level Explanation: Hemisection of the spinal cord (as shown in the image) results in I/L loss of Dorsal and Pyramidal column tracts and C/L loss of Spinothalamic tract (STT) 2 segments below the level of lesion is known as Brown-Sequard syndrome . As STT (specifically Lateral STT) relays at the dorsal root ganglion and crosses over at 1-2 segments above the level of that spinal cord. Brown-Sequard syndrome: Hemisection of Spinal Cord Ipsilateral (I/L) Contralateral (C/L) At the level of lesion CST: LMN paralysis Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception Radicular pain + - Below the level of lesion CST: UMN paralysis Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception Spinothalamic tract: Loss of Pain and Temperature

questions.question: A 30 year old vegetarian female was referred to Neurology OPD with complaints of progressive weakness of lower limbs, numbness, difficulty walking and recent onset forgetfulness. On examination, there was B/L loss of vibration sense, Deep tendon reflexes - absent, Babinski-positive and Positive Romberg sign was noted. Peripheral blood smear done was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal cord

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal cord Explanation: Ataxia with both UMN (Positive Babinski) & LMN (DTR-absent) signs positive, dorsal column involvement (loss of vibration sense) and positive romberg sign is suggestive of Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal Cord (SACD) . SACD however, occurs secondary to Vitamin B12 deficiency, can present without macrocytosis. Subacute combined degeneration: Description Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts Etiology Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians), Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection Clinical features Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement Ataxia: Romberg sign positive DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement) Dementia: Reversible with therapy Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints Investigations Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation Peripheral blood smear: May reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well Management Vitamin B12 supplementation Differential diagnosis Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked Tabes Dorsalis (Option B): Associated with Syphilis, Dorsal columns involved Argyll Robertson pupils - present Bladder involvement - present Friedreich Ataxia (Option C): Age: Usually in the 2nd decade (<25 years) Trinucleotide GAA repeats - Chromosome 9, Autosomal recessive inheritance Associations: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (cause of death) , Pes cavus, Diabetes mellitus, Vitamin-E deficiency Brown Sequard syndrome (Option D): Hemisection of spinal cord Ipsilateral loss of Dorsal column + Contralateral Spinothalamic tract seen

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden symmetrical onset of both lower extremity weakness, numbness, and urinary retention. She reports a history of a respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. Neurological examination reveals reduced muscle strength and sensory loss below the mid-thoracic region, along with hyperreflexia. MRI of the spine shows a focal area of increased T2 signal in the thoracic spinal cord without evidence of compression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Transverse myelitis Explanation: Rapid onset B/L symmetrical weakness post-infective sequelae with Hyperintensities within the spinal cord on T2-MRI is suggestive of Transverse Myelitis . Transverse Myelitis: Introduction Acquired focal inflammatory disorder of spinal cord Etio- pathogenesis Idiopathic: Most common Post-infectious: Usually Enterovirus, Herpes, HIV Inflammatory/Autoimmune: Ankylosing spondylitis, APLA syndrome, Behcet disease, RA, Scleroderma Multifocal CNS disorders: Multiple sclerosis, Neurosarcoidosis Clinical features Motor: Sudden onset B/L usually symmetric rapid paralysis initially flaccidity, and later spasticity sets in. Sensory: Pain, Dysaesthesia, Paraesthesia Autonomic: Bowel/bladder disturbances + , impotence + Backache: Corresponding to the level of lesion Diagnosis T2-MRI: Focal Hyperintense signals within the spinal cord CSF Analysis: To rule out other infectious/inflammatory etiology, elevated IgG index may be present Histopathology: Perivascular infiltration of monocytes/lymphocytes + demyelination +/- axonal injury Management First line: High dose IV Glucocorticoids Plasmapheresis Other immunomodulators: Cyclophosphamide, Mycophenolate, Rituximab Multiple sclerosis (Option A): MS can present with spinal cord lesions, but typically these are asymmetrical and multifocal . This patient’s rapid, symmetrical onset of symptoms and the absence of other characteristic findings like Optic neuritis, Lhermitte sign, Uhthoff’s phenomenon , MRI shows characteristic Dawson’s fingers and CSF analysis reveals Oligoclonal bands - thereby making MS less likely. Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option B): GBS often presents with ascending asymmetric weakness and areflexia , affecting peripheral nerves. CSF analysis reveals Albumino-cytological dissociation. However, this patient has hyperreflexia and sensory loss in a well-defined spinal cord region, which is more indicative of central nervous system pathology, ruling out GBS. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option D): ALS causes progressive motor neuron degeneration, leading to both upper and lower motor neuron signs without sensory deficits . The acute onset, sensory involvement, and bladder dysfunction are not typical of ALS. Reference: https://www.ninds.nih.gov/health-information/disorders/transverse-myelitis

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset lower back pain and bilateral lower limb weakness. On examination, there is saddle anesthesia, knee jerk-intact and ankle jerk-absent. What is the most likely diagnosis and its corresponding onset of bladder involvement?

options.A: Conus medullaris syndrome, Early bladder involvement
options.B: Cauda Equina Syndrome, Early bladder involvement
options.C: Conus medullaris syndrome, Late bladder involvement
options.D: Cauda Equina Syndrome, Late bladder involvement

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Conus medullaris syndrome, Early bladder involvement Explanation: Conus Medullaris Syndrome results from damage to the terminal portion of the spinal cord. Key features include: Sudden onset of back pain Bilateral symptoms Early involvement of bowel/bladder dysfunction (incontinence) Saddle anesthesia, intact knee jerk and absent ankle jerk Conus Medullaris syndrome Cauda Equina syndrome Nerve roots S1-S5 (Purely sacral) Lumbar + Sacral Presentation Sudden and bilateral symmetric Back Pain- more severe Gradual and unilateral asymmetric Pain- less severe Radicular pain Severe Mild-moderate Knee jerk Preserved Absent Ankle jerk Absent Absent Sensory loss More localized to perianal area: Saddle anesthesia + Patchy loss along the lower limb: Radicular pattern distribution Motor loss Less marked, symmetric More marked, asymmetric Bowel/bladder involvement Frequent and early onset Late onset Impotence Present Less frequent Reference: Davidson’s Principles & Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Pages 326,1327.

questions.question: A 54-year-old male has a herniated disk that has damaged his L3-L5 nerve roots. Which of the following is least likely to be his clinical feature?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Brisk bulbocavernosus reflex Explanation: The scenario is Cauda Equina Syndrome. Bulbocavernous reflex is absent in cauda equina syndrome Cauda Equina Syndrome: Definition Compression and disruption of the nerve roots from the distal spinal cord (typically L1-L5), often resulting from damage (secondary to trauma, tumors, herniated discs , or spinal stenosis ) to L3-L5 nerve roots Clinical features - Back pain and sciatica (Option A ruled out) - Bladder dysfunction (retention or incontinence) - Bowel dysfunction (retention or incontinence) - Saddle anesthesia (Option B ruled out) - Sexual dysfunction (impotence in men). (Option D ruled out) - Motor or sensory deficits in the legs, often asymmetric. - Lower motor neuron signs: areflexia, hypotonia, atrophy. - Decreased rectal tone. - Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (Option C) Diagnosis - Urgent MRI with sagittal and axial T1 and T2 sequences is the gold standard. - CT myelogram for patients contraindicated for MRI. - Bladder scan to check post-void residual volume for urinary retention. Management Surgical decompression (laminectomy, discectomy, or sequestrectomy) with early neurosurgical or orthopedic consultation. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537200/

questions.question: Which of the following statements is wrong on conus medullaris?

options.B: Affects the sacral and single coccygeal segments
options.D: Loss of muscle strength on inner thighs

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Loss of muscle strength on inner thighs Explanation: Muscle strength is largely preserved in Cous Medullaris Sacral Cord/Conus Medullaris: Definition Tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord (Option A ruled out) , comprising the sacral and single coccygeal segments (Option B ruled out) Symptoms Bilateral saddle anesthesia (S3–S5) (Option C ruled out) involving the perineum, inner thighs, and buttocks. Prominent urinary retention, incontinence, and lax anal tone. Impotence is common due to the involvement of sacral segments. Largely preserved muscle strength. (Option D) Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (S2–S4) and anal reflex (S4–S5). Typically minimal or absent pain. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page 3446

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and sensory loss in her arms, along with muscle wasting in her hands. MRI reveals a large intramedullary spinal cord tumor, with an associated syrinx. What is the management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Tumor resection Explanation: Tumor resection is preferred in Syrinx secondary to intramedullary spinal cord tumors Syringomyelia: Diagnosis MRI to detect syrinx cavities, spinal cord enlargement, assess Chiari malformation, and determine hydrocephalus. Treatment Chiari malformation treatment: Suboccipital craniectomy, cervical laminectomy, dural graft placement. Hydrocephalus with Chiari: Shunting precedes syrinx correction. Syrinx secondary to trauma/infection: Decompression and drainage (shunt or fenestration). Syrinx due to intramedullary spinal cord tumors: Tumor resection is preferred. Note: Patients with minimal symptoms do not require surgery and are monitored with clinical and imaging follow-up. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page 3453

questions.question: Which of the following statements about syringomyelia is wrong?

options.A: A developmental cavity in the cervical cord
options.B: Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood
options.C: The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation
options.D: Sensory loss in a cape distribution

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation Explanation: More than half of syringomyelia cases are linked with Chiari type 1 malformations . Syringomyelia: Definition A developmental cavity in the cervical cord (Option A ruled out) that can enlarge or remain asymptomatic. Onset & Progression Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood (Option B ruled out) , progress irregularly, and may undergo spontaneous arrest. Common Association More than half of cases are linked with Chiari type 1 malformations (cerebellar tonsils protrude through the foramen magnum and cervical spinal canal). (Option C) Pathophysiology Possibly related to interference with CSF flow, particularly due to Chiari malformations. Presentation Dissociated sensory loss (pain and temperature loss, touch and vibration spared) . Areflexic weakness in upper limbs . Suspended sensory loss in a cape distribution (nape, shoulders, upper arms, hands). (Option D ruled out) Muscle wasting in neck, shoulders, arms, hands; absent/asymmetric reflexes in arms. As syrinx expands: Spasticity, leg weakness, bladder/bowel dysfunction, Horner's syndrome. Facial numbness from trigeminal damage (C2 level or above) . spinal cord" data-author="NA" data-hash="9035" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="" height="373" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/cqGMDNcY4iGS75Se4iXe1744336455.png" width="373" /> Additional Symptoms Chiari-associated symptoms: Cough-induced headache, neck, arm, or facial pain. Syringobulbia: Palatal/vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, nystagmus, vertigo, tongue weakness.

questions.question: Which gene mutation is primarily associated with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) SCN4A Explanation: Mutations in the SCN4A gene , which encodes a sodium channel, are primarily responsible for hyperkalemic periodic paralysis. Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis Periodic paralysis is a group of inherited diseases that present as episodic muscle weakness and paralysis. Begins in childhood and can continue until middle adulthood or may even last into late adulthood. Etiopathogenesis : It is caused by a point mutation in the SCN4A gene. This gene encodes proteins responsible for sodium transport in skeletal muscles. Mutant SCN4A protein channels malfunction by allowing too much sodium into skeletal muscles by staying open too long or not staying closed long enough. This additional influx of sodium triggers a release of intracellular potassium from the skeletal muscles. Subsequently, this change in ion transport impairs a muscle's ability to contract, leading to weakness or paralysis. Clinical features: Patients typically present in the first or second decade of life with intermittent bouts of weakness or paralysis in the hips, shoulders, and back triggered by diet, stress, or exercise. Attacks are generally intermittent and last 15 minutes to 1 hour. Common triggers are potassium-rich foods, a cold environment, and rest after physical activity. Diagnosis : Diagnostic criteria are as follows: 2 or more attacks of weakness with serum potassium greater than 4.5 mEq/L or 1 attack in the patient with a relative with 1 attack with serum potassium greater than 4.5 mEq/L. 3 of the 6 following clinical or laboratory features can also assist in making a diagnosis: Symptom onset before age 30 Attacks must last less than 2 hours Identifiable triggers, myotonia Family history Confirmed genetic testing for sodium channel mutation in the SCN4A Positive McManis short exercise test. Treatment: The treatment approach should include both the management of acute attacks and the prevention of attacks. Individuals may prevent attacks by consuming frequent carbohydrate-rich meals, a thiazide diuretic, or a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (Acetazolamide). Individuals should avoid potassium-rich medications and foods, fasting, strenuous work, and exposure to cold to prevent attacks. Prophylactic treatment necessitates serum potassium levels twice yearly to avoid diuretic complications and annual evaluation of thyroid function. KCNJ2 (Option A): Associated with Anderson-Tawil syndrome and hypokalemic periodic paralysis. CACNA1S (Option B): Mutations in this gene are linked to hypokalemic periodic paralysis and other channelopathies. RYR1 (Option D): Mutations in this gene are associated with malignant hyperthermia and central core disease. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564319/

questions.question: A 60-year-old female is admitted to the ICU following a subarachnoid hemorrhage. On examination, she is stuporous, exhibits intermittent reflex posturing and has severe motor deficits. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 8. What is her grade of subarachnoid hemorrhage according to both the Hunt-Hess scale and the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) scale?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hunt-Hess Grade 4, WFNS Grade 4 Explanation : Hunt-Hess Grade 4: Stupor, moderate to severe motor deficits, with intermittent reflex posturing. This describes the patient’s condition accurately. WFNS Grade 4: GCS score of 7–12, with or without motor deficits. The patient’s GCS of 8 fits within this range. Grading Scales for Subarachnoid Hemorrhage GRADE HUNT-HESS SCALE WORLD FEDERATION OF NEUROSURGICAL SOCIETIES (WFNS) SCALE 1 Mild headache, normal mental status, no cranial nerve or motor findings GCS score 15, no motor deficits 2 Severe headache, normal mental status, may have cranial nerve deficit GCS score 13–14, no motor deficits 3 Somnolent, confused , may have cranial nerve or mild motor deficit GCS score 13–14, with motor deficits 4 Stupor , moderate to severe motor deficit, may have intermittent posturing GCS score 7–12, with or without motor deficits 5 Coma, reflex posturing or flaccid GCS score 3–6, with or without motor deficits Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st Edition, Page 3354

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as the "worst of their life." A non-contrast head CT scan is performed but returns negative. Despite this, the suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) remains high. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

options.A: Repeat the head CT scan in 24 hours
options.B: Lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for xanthochromia
options.D: Perform a Time-of-Flight Magnetic Resonance Angiography (TOF-MRA)

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for xanthochromia Explanation: Lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for xanthochromia is the next step if the initial CT scan is negative but clinical suspicion for SAH remains high. Ideally, the LP should be performed at least 6 hours after the headache onset to detect xanthochromia, which indicates blood breakdown in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Initial Evaluation of Suspected Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) Head CT: First-line imaging to detect SAH. CT Angiography : Performed if SAH is identified on CT to determine the a neurysm's location and size. If negative, follow with cerebral angiography (Option C ruled out) or digital subtraction angiography (DSA). TOF-MRA (Time-of-Flight Magnetic Resonance Angiography): A non-contrast imaging option, suitable for patients allergic to contrast or with reduced kidney function . (Option D ruled out) Lumbar Puncture (LP): Done if the initial CT is negative but suspicion remains high. Ideally performed 6 hours after the CT to detect xanthochromia (yellow discoloration in cerebrospinal fluid). Xanthochromia is often visible at the bedside. Sensitivity Considerations: CT Scans and RBC Counts : Highly sensitive early in diagnosis but decrease over time due to the fast flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). (Option A ruled out) RBC Lysis: RBCs in the CSF break down over time, producing bilirubin and oxyhemoglobin, making xanthochromia more detectable after several hours. Diagnostic Protocols Lumbar Puncture Before Imaging: Only if CT is unavailable. Four-Vessel Conventional X-ray Angiography: Typically performed to localize the aneurysm and check for additional unruptured aneurysms. Endovascular Treatment: In some centers, endovascular techniques are performed during the angiogram to minimize invasive procedures. CT Angiography: An alternative for aneurysm localization and treatment planning.

questions.question: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, described as "the worst headache of her life." She was unresponsive at home, and, on arrival, was stuporous, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 10. A CT scan confirms a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). On the fourth day of her hospitalisation, she becomes increasingly drowsy, and her speech slows down. A repeat CT scan reveals no new haemorrhage or infarct. Her serum sodium level is 125 mEq/L. What is the most likely cause of this patient's deterioration?

options.D: Hyponatremia due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hyponatremia due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome Explanation : Hyponatremia occurs in the first two weeks after SAH due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome, leading to volume depletion and mental status changes, as seen in this patient. Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Delayed neurological deficits Rerupture Incidence: ~30% in the first month, with peak in the first 7 days. Mortality rate: 50%. Prevention: Early treatment eliminates risk. Hydrocephalus Acute Hydrocephalus : Causes stupor/coma; managed by external ventricular drain. Subacute Hydrocephalus: Develops over days/weeks; causes drowsiness, slowed thinking, and incontinence. Diagnosed via CT, CTA, TCD ultrasound, or x-ray angiography. (Option B ruled out) Chronic Hydrocephalus : Weeks/months after SAH, with symptoms like gait difficulty, incontinence, or cognitive impairment. Delayed Cerebral Ischemia (DCI) (Option C ruled out) Cause: Vasospasm of arteries at the brain’s base, causing ischemia and infarction (~30% of patients). Onset: 4–14 days after hemorrhage (peaks at 7 days). Mechanism: Triggered by blood clots/ breakdown products. More surrounding blood increases vasospasm risk. Symptoms : Sudden focal deficits, mental decline, fluctuating symptoms . Detection: X-ray angiography, TCD ultrasound, or CTA. Treatment: CSF drainage, mannitol/ hypertonic saline, hemicraniectomy, moderate hypothermia. Hyponatremia Onset: Occurs in the first 2 weeks post-SAH due to natriuresis and volume depletion (hyponatremia + hypovolemia). Cause: Involves atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (cerebral salt-wasting syndrome). Treatment: Resolves in 1–2 weeks. Free-water restriction is avoided to reduce stroke risk. Rebleeding of the aneurysm (Option A): It usually causes acute neurological deterioration with signs of intracranial pressure elevation, such as rapid onset coma, which is not consistent with this patient's gradual decline in consciousness. Reference: 1. Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st Edition, Page 3354 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441958/

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of her life." She also reports vomiting. Imaging confirms a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) due to a rupture of aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. Which of the following clinical features is most likely associated with this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Third cranial nerve palsy Explanation : Third cranial nerve palsy is typically seen with an aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. It presents with symptoms like pupillary dilation, loss of the ipsilateral light reflex, and eye pain. Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Clinical features and features based on location of bleed Unruptured Aneurysms Typically asymptomatic but may cause cranial nerve or brain parenchyma compression (mass effect). Prodromal Symptoms: Third Cranial Nerve Palsy: Seen with an expanding aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. Symptoms include pupillary dilation, ipsilateral light reflex loss, and eye pain. Cranial Nerve" data-author="NA" data-hash="9032" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="" height="361" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/0H16GJl9IG0DiaELM7xX1744336055.png" width="361" /> Sixth Nerve Palsy: May suggest an aneurysm in the cavernous sinus. (Option A ruled out) Visual Field Defects : May occur with an aneurysm in the supraclinoid carotid or anterior cerebral artery (ACA). (Option B ruled out) Occipital/ Cervical Pain: Seen with posterior inferior or anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysms. (Option D ruled out) Eye/Temple Pain: Expanding middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysms can cause pain in or behind the eye and temple. Ruptured Aneurysms Sudden ICP increase: Occurs at the moment of rupture, often causing transient loss of consciousness in nearly 50% of patients. Headache : Excruciating headaches may precede before the rupture, but most patients report severe headache after regaining consciousness. The primary symptom is a sudden severe headache during exertion, often described as "the worst headache of my life". Some cases may present with moderate headache or changes in usual headache patterns. Additional Symptoms: Generalized headache with neck stiffness and vomiting is common. Focal Neurologic Deficits: May occur if the aneurysm bleeds into the brain or subdural space, causing a hematoma. Deficits include: Hemiparesis, aphasia, mental slowness (abulia). Severe Cases: 10% of patients may lose consciousness for several days due to significant bleeding. Sentinel Bleeds: Small, earlier ruptures causing unexplained headache can precede major SAH, signaling imminent hemorrhage. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Page 3353, 3354 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441958/

questions.question: A 62-year-old female presents to the ER with a sudden onset of the "worst headache of her life." A CT scan confirms a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). After stabilization, further imaging reveals an aneurysm in the posterior circulation. Her relatives informed her that she had a past history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Which of the following is most strongly associated with an increased risk of rupture of this aneurysm? A) Aneurysm size of 3 cm B) Location in the posterior circulation C) Hypertension D) Age over 60 years E) History of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All the above Explanation : Each of the factors listed contributes significantly to an increased risk of aneurysm rupture. Subarachnoid hemorrhage Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space. Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma . Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm . Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life). Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI). Epidemiology: Age/ Gender: Most of the SAH occurs between age of 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females. Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk. Etiology: Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH): Risk Factors: Hypertension , smoking , family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs , and estrogen deficiency . Rupture Risk: (Option D) Age >60 Posterior circulation aneurysms Atherosclerosis Aneurysm size Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk. Aneurysms ≥ 10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk. Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year. Family history Previous SAH ADPKD Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH): Perimesencephalic NASAH : Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course. Occult Aneurysm : Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging. Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions. Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods. Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders. Pathophysiology: Hemodynamic Stress : Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations. Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow. Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture. Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

questions.question: A 20 Y/O female presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent muscle weakness, which often follows periods of rest after exercise. She also reports occasional episodes of palpitations. On examination, she has mild facial dysmorphism, including a broad forehead, a small jaw, and low-set ears. Her pulse is irregular, and an ECG shows frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with occasional runs of bidirectional ventricular tachycardia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the KCNJ2 gene. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

options.A: Sodium channelopathy affecting the cardiac conduction system
options.B: Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction
options.D: Abnormal chloride transport in skeletal and cardiac muscle

Anderson-Tawil Syndrome (ATS) Etiopathogenesis : Anderson-Tawil syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder, part of the spectrum of channelopathies, specifically a type of periodic paralysis. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the KCNJ2 gene located on chromosome 17, which encodes the Kir 2.1 inward-rectifier potassium channel. This results in dysfunction of potassium ion flow, leading to both skeletal muscle and cardiac abnormalities. Mutation in the *KCNJ2* gene affects potassium channels in the heart, skeletal muscle, and smooth muscle. The potassium channel dysfunction leads to disruptions in cellular membrane polarization, manifesting as periodic muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and other symptoms. Clinical Features: The hallmark of Anderson-Tawil syndrome involves a triad of symptoms: Periodic paralysis Ventricular arrhythmias Prolonged QT interval Dysmorphic Features: Craniofacial abnormalities such as a broad forehead, small mandible, low-set ears, and hypertelorism (wide-spaced eyes). Skeletal abnormalities like short stature, scoliosis, and clinodactyly (curvature of fingers), syndactyly. Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical findings, genetic testing, and supportive investigations. Electrocardiogram (ECG): Identification of characteristic arrhythmias such as frequent PVCs or bidirectional ventricular tachycardia. Electromyography (EMG): EMG may show muscle fiber irritability during episodes of weakness. Serum Electrolytes: Monitoring of serum potassium levels during episodes of muscle weakness. Hypokalemia is often seen but normal or hyperkalemia can also occur. Genetic Testing: Testing for *KCNJ2* gene mutations confirm the diagnosis. Differential Diagnosis: Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis Hyperkalemic Periodic Paralysis Thyrotoxic Periodic Paralysis Long QT syndrome Treatment : Potassium supplementation (20-30mEq/L): Oral potassium can help alleviate hypokalemic episodes. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide): These are used to prevent episodes of paralysis. They help stabilize muscle membrane potential. Avoidance of triggers: Maintaining stable potassium level, avoiding fasting, and reducing strenuous exercise can help reduce the frequency of attacks. Cardiac Management: Beta-blockers Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) Antiarrhythmic drugs (flecainide, amiodarone)

questions.question: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of generalized muscle weakness, particularly in his legs, after a day of strenuous exercise followed by a high-carbohydrate meal. He reports experiencing similar episodes of muscle weakness in the past, often triggered by exercise or large meals. His ECG shows U waves. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient’s acute presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Oral potassium supplementation Explanation : In most cases of acute hypokalemic periodic paralysis, oral potassium supplementation is preferred as the first-line treatment , especially when the patient's symptoms are not life-threatening and potassium levels are moderately low. Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (HypoPP) It is a genetic disorder, caused by skeletal muscle ion channel mutation, mainly affecting sodium or calcium channels. The majority of hypoPP cases are hereditary or familial. The familial form of hypoPP is a rare channelopathy resulting from mutations in either the calcium or sodium ion channels, predominantly affecting skeletal muscle cells. Etiopathogenesis: Genetics : Autosomal dominant mutations in voltage-gated calcium channels ( CACNA1S ) or sodium channels ( SCN4A ). The most common familial form, type 1 hypoPP , is characterized by a mutation in the dihydropyridine-sensitive skeletal muscle calcium channel gene, CACNA1S. On the other hand, the type 2 familial form of hypoPP is associated with mutations in the voltage-sensitive skeletal muscle sodium channel gene, SCN4A . Mechanism : Abnormal ion channel function leads to impaired muscle cell depolarisation and muscle weakness during attacks. Mutation in the calcium channel revealed abnormal sarcolemmal ATP-sensitive K+ (KATP) channel function. This was supported by the lack of stimulation of the channel by magnesium adenosine diphosphate (MgADP), which is likely associated with depolarization during hypokalemia. Triggers : Common triggers: Carbohydrate-rich meals, strenuous exercise followed by rest, stress, and cold exposure. Clinical Features: The mean age of presentation of attacks is the first or second decade of life during teenage or childhood. Episodic weakness: Sudden onset of flaccid paralysis, typically affecting proximal muscles more than distal. Pattern : Weakness usually begins in the legs and progresses to the arms, sparing respiratory and ocular muscles. The pattern of muscle weakness is similar in both familial and thyrotoxic hypoPP, and signs of hyperthyroidism are often evident in most cases of thyrotoxic hypoPP. Hyporeflexia or Areflexia is a common finding. Muscle weakness between attacks that improves with mild exercise. Respiratory muscle involvement in severe cases. Diagnosis : HypoPP is suspected when an individual presents with a sudden attack of flaccid muscle weakness involving proximal muscles, accompanied by either decreased or normal deep tendon reflexes, especially after exposure to known triggering factors. However, without a family history, a low serum potassium level during a typical weakness episode helps establish the diagnosis. Serum potassium levels: Low during attacks (hypokalemia). ECG : May show U waves, prolonged QT interval, or arrhythmias during hypokalemia. Genetic testing : Identifies mutations in the CACNA1S or SCN4A genes.

questions.question: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe muscle weakness, primarily in his legs, which started a few hours after consuming a large, carbohydrate-heavy meal following exercise. He reports similar episodes in the past, often triggered by large meals or after rest following physical activity. His vital signs are stable, and he has no respiratory involvement. Blood work reveals a serum potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's condition?

options.A: Sodium channel dysfunction causing an inability to generate action potentials
options.B: Potassium channel dysfunction leading to excessive potassium loss
options.C: Calcium or sodium channel mutations causing abnormal potassium influx into cells

questions.question: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle stiffness, especially in his face and hands, following exposure to cold weather. He reports that his symptoms worsen with repeated movements and improve with rest. Upon examination, his muscles are stiff but not weak. His symptoms do not improve with warming .What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Paramyotonia Congenita Explanation: This patient presents with classic symptoms of Paramyotonia Congenita , which include muscle stiffness triggered by cold exposure and exacerbation with continued activity. Paramyotonia Congenita: Paramyotonia Congenita (PC) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the SCN4A gene located in the 17q chromosome , which encodes the alpha subunit of the voltage-gated sodium channels in skeletal muscle. Pathophysiology : Mutations in the SCN4A gene lead to defective sodium channels, resulting in impaired muscle membrane excitability. This causes prolonged depolarization of muscle cells and delayed relaxation, leading to muscle stiffness (myotonia). Triggers : The primary triggers for paramyotonia include cold exposure, repetitive activity . Clinical Features: Muscle Stiffness (Myotonia): Stiffness occurs after cold exposure, particularly affecting the facial muscles (eyelids, lips) and distal muscles (hands). Stiffness worsens with repeated movements (paradoxical myotonia) and improves with rest. Weakness : Temporary muscle weakness may follow the stiffness, especially after prolonged cold exposure or exercise. Cold Sensitivity: Patients often experience increased muscle stiffness when exposed to cold temperatures. Diagnosis : Clinical History and Examination: Diagnosis is often based on the patient’s symptoms, especially the cold-induced muscle stiffness and paradoxical worsening with repeated movements. Electromyography (EMG): EMG typically shows myotonic discharges (repetitive muscle action potentials) that persist with activity. Genetic Testing: Mutations in the SCN4A gene can confirm the diagnosis. Cold Test: Cooling specific muscles (forearm) can provoke symptoms of stiffness or weakness, aiding in diagnosis. Treatment : Avoid Cold Exposure: Patients should avoid cold environments to prevent symptoms. Gradual Warming : In cold environments, gradual warming may help reduce symptoms. Medications : Mexiletine : A sodium channel blocker that helps reduce myotonia by stabilizing the muscle membrane. Acetazolamide : It can help reduce muscle stiffness and prevent attacks. Physical Therapy: Regular gentle exercises may help maintain muscle function and avoid stiffness. Myotonic Dystrophy (Option A): Muscle stiffness with systemic features, not triggered by cold. Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (Option C): Episodes of weakness, not stiffness, triggered by low potassium. Becker Muscular Dystrophy (Option D): Progressive muscle weakness, not cold-triggered stiffness. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/113142
